questions.text: What is the fundamental problem that the study of economics addresses?
options: #Scarcity of resources relative to human wants
The elimination of poverty in developing nations
The management of government tax revenues
The fluctuation of prices in the stock market

questions.text: Scarcity exists because:
options: #Human wants are unlimited while resources are limited
Governments fail to distribute goods fairly
Firms do not use enough technology in production
The global population is growing too slowly

questions.text: Which of the following best illustrates the concept of scarcity?
options: #A student choosing between studying for an hour or sleeping for an hour
A store running out of a popular toy during the holidays
A person having enough money to buy everything they want
An abundance of natural gas discovered in a new field

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the concept of efficiency?
options: #Society getting the maximum benefits from its scarce resources
Distributing economic prosperity uniformly among all members
Ensuring that government regulations are strictly followed
Keeping the unemployment rate at exactly zero percent

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the concept of equality in economics?
options: #Distributing economic prosperity uniformly among members of society
Producing the highest possible quality of goods
Allowing the market to determine all prices without intervention
Maximizing the total profit of all firms in a nation

questions.text: Which of the following best describes rational people in economics?
options: #People who systematically and purposefully do the best they can to achieve their objectives
People who never make mistakes when predicting the future
People who only care about money and ignore all social costs
People who always choose the cheapest option available

questions.text: Which of the following best describes an incentive in economics?
options: #Something that induces a person to act, such as a prospect of a punishment or reward
A legal requirement enforced by the government
The total cost of producing a specific good
A psychological state of being satisfied with a purchase

questions.text: A marginal change is one that:
options: #Describes a small incremental adjustment to an existing plan of action
Changes the entire structure of the national economy
Occurs only when a firm goes bankrupt
Is irrelevant to the decision-making process of a rational person

questions.text: Because people respond to incentives,
options: #Policymakers must consider how their laws change the costs or benefits for citizens
Prices in a market economy will always remain constant
The government does not need to intervene in the economy
People will ignore the marginal costs of their actions

questions.text: According to the principle of opportunity cost, what is the cost of an economic decision?
options: #Whatever must be given up to obtain some item
The total monetary value spent on the decision
The time spent researching the different options
The psychological stress caused by making a choice

questions.text: Which principle suggests that people make decisions by comparing marginal benefits and marginal costs?
options: #Rational people think at the margin
Trade can make everyone better off
The invisible hand principle
The law of diminishing returns

questions.text: International trade benefits a nation when:
options: #It allows countries to specialize in what they do best
The nation exports more than it imports
It forces domestic firms to lower their quality
The government imposes high tariffs on all imports

questions.text: Adam Smith's "invisible hand" refers to:
options: #How households and firms acting in their own self-interest lead to desirable market outcomes
The secret interventions of the central bank to control inflation
The way government regulations subtly guide the economy
The automated systems used in modern manufacturing

questions.text: Governments may intervene in a market economy in order to:
options: #Promote efficiency or promote equality
Ensure that all firms make an equal amount of profit
Prevent any changes in the equilibrium price
Control the personal choices of every consumer

questions.text: Which of the following is a positive, rather than a normative, statement?
options: #An increase in the minimum wage will lead to a higher rate of unemployment
The government should increase the minimum wage to help the poor
The minimum wage is too low for a family to live on comfortably
It is unfair that some people earn more than others

questions.text: The following parts of government regularly rely on the advice of economists:
options: #The Department of the Treasury, the Department of Labor, and the Department of Justice
The Department of Defense and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)
The Department of Education and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)
All of the above

questions.text: Economists may disagree because they have different:
options: #Scientific judgments or different values
Access to data or different educational backgrounds
Political affiliations or different cultural upbringings
Levels of intelligence or different life experiences

questions.text: In an hour, Mateo can wash 2 cars or mow 1 lawn, and Sophia can wash 3 cars or mow 1 lawn. Who has the absolute advantage?
options: #Sophia in washing cars, while neither has an absolute advantage in mowing lawns
Mateo in washing cars and Sophia in mowing lawns
Sophia in both washing cars and mowing lawns
Mateo in both washing cars and mowing lawns

questions.text: In an hour, Mateo can wash 2 cars or mow 1 lawn, and Sophia can wash 3 cars or mow 1 lawn. Who has the comparative advantage?
options: #Mateo in mowing lawns and Sophia in washing cars
Mateo in washing cars and Sophia in mowing lawns
Sophia in both washing cars and mowing lawns
Mateo in both washing cars and mowing lawns

questions.text: A nation will typically import those goods in which:
options: #Other nations have a comparative advantage
It has a comparative advantage
It has an absolute advantage
The domestic price is higher than the world price

questions.text: If producing an aircraft and a shirt requires different labor hours in the U.S. and China, what will these nations trade?
options: #The good in which each country has a comparative advantage
The good in which each country has an absolute advantage
Only the goods that are not produced in both countries
They will not trade if one country is more efficient at producing both goods

questions.text: Kayla cooks dinner in 30 minutes and washes laundry in 20 minutes; her roommate takes twice as long. How should the work be allocated?
options: #They should both specialize based on their comparative advantages
Kayla should do all the work because she is faster at both
The roommate should do all the work to gain more experience
They should split each task equally between them

questions.text: When Mateo and Sophia specialize and trade based on comparative advantage, what happens?
options: #Both can consume more of both goods than they could without trade
Mateo benefits but Sophia loses
Sophia benefits but Mateo loses
The total output of both goods remains the same

questions.text: Most economists believe that tariffs are:
options: #Harmful because they reduce the gains from trade
Beneficial because they protect domestic industries and jobs
Necessary to ensure fair competition in international markets
Only effective in the short run to promote economic growth

questions.text: What is the best definition of a market?
options: #A group of buyers and sellers of a particular good or service
A physical location where goods are exchanged for money
The set of laws and regulations that govern economic activity
A specific industry that is dominated by a few large firms

questions.text: In a perfectly competitive market,
options: #There are many buyers and sellers, such that each has a negligible impact on the market price
Firms have total control over the price of the goods they sell
Only a few large companies dominate the entire industry
The goods offered for sale are highly differentiated

questions.text: Which product best fits the definition of a perfectly competitive market?
options: #Wheat
Smartphones
Commercial aircraft
Luxury cars

questions.text: What is the primary characteristic of a market economy?
options: #Resources are allocated through the decentralized decisions of many firms and households
A central planning authority decides what goods and services will be produced
The government owns all of the factors of production
Prices are fixed by law to ensure they are affordable for everyone

questions.text: What is an economic model?
options: #A simplified representation of reality used to understand economic behavior
A detailed map of every transaction that occurs in an economy
A set of rules that all businesses must follow
A mathematical equation that predicts the future with 100% accuracy

questions.text: In the circular-flow diagram, in markets for the factors of production:
options: #Households are sellers and firms are buyers
Firms are sellers and households are buyers
The government acts as the only buyer and seller
Only services are traded, not goods

questions.text: A point inside the production possibilities frontier is:
options: #Feasible but inefficient
Infeasible given current resources and technology
Both efficient and feasible
Where the economy should aim to produce to maximize welfare

questions.text: All of the following topics fall within microeconomics EXCEPT:
options: #The influence of the government budget deficit on economic growth
The effect of rent control on the housing market in New York City
The impact of foreign competition on the U.S. auto industry
The factors that influence a consumer's decision to buy a car

questions.text: Which economic system relies on supply and demand to allocate resources?
options: #Market economy
Command economy
Traditional economy
Barter economy

questions.text: A change in which variable does NOT shift the demand curve for hamburgers?
options: #The price of hamburgers
The price of hot dogs (a substitute)
Consumer income
The expected future price of hamburgers

questions.text: Which event shifts the demand curve for pizza to the right?
options: #An increase in the price of hamburgers (a substitute)
A decrease in the price of pizza
A scientific study showing that pizza is bad for your health
A decrease in the number of pizza buyers

questions.text: If pasta is an inferior good, how does its demand change when income rises?
options: #Demand decreases
Demand increases
Demand remains unchanged
Quantity demanded decreases, but demand stays the same

questions.text: In a command economy, who decides what and how much to produce?
options: #The government
Individual consumers
Business owners
Market forces

questions.text: Which economic system combines market and command elements?
options: #Mixed economy
Pure market economy
Pure command economy
Traditional economy

questions.text: What does "invisible hand" refer to in economic theory?
options: #The self-regulating nature of the marketplace
The government's intervention in the economy
The impact of technology on production
The control of large corporations over prices

questions.text: Which good is likely to have a more inelastic demand?
options: #Life-saving insulin
A brand of potato chips
Tickets to a concert
A luxury yacht

questions.text: What is the main difference between economic profit and accounting profit?
options: #Economic profit considers both explicit and implicit costs, while accounting profit only considers explicit costs
Accounting profit considers both explicit and implicit costs, while economic profit only considers explicit costs
Economic profit is always higher than accounting profit
Accounting profit is only used by large corporations

questions.text: If a firm's marginal product of labor is 10, what does this mean?
options: #Hiring one more worker increases total output by 10 units
The firm produces 10 units for every worker it employs
The cost of hiring one more worker is $10
The firm's total profit increases by $10 when it hires one more worker

questions.text: What does diminishing marginal product of labor indicate?
options: #As more workers are hired, the extra output produced by each additional worker decreases
The total output of the firm decreases as more workers are hired
The firm should stop hiring workers immediately
The cost of labor is increasing

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of perfectly competitive markets?
options: #The goods offered by the various sellers are largely the same
There are only a few sellers in the market
Firms have significant power to set their own prices
There are high barriers to entry for new firms

questions.text: In a perfectly competitive market, each firm is a:
options: #Price taker
Price maker
Monopolist
Oligopolist

questions.text: What is the main goal of a firm in a perfectly competitive market?
options: #To maximize profit
To maximize total revenue
To minimize total cost
To provide the best possible service to customers

questions.text: The demand curve facing a perfectly competitive firm is:
options: #Perfectly elastic
Perfectly inelastic
Downward sloping
Upward sloping

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of monopolistic competition?
options: #Many firms selling products that are similar but not identical
One firm selling a product with no close substitutes
A few firms selling products that are identical
High barriers to entry and exit

questions.text: What is a key feature of an oligopoly?
options: #The market is dominated by a small number of large firms
There are no barriers to entry or exit
Firms have no influence over the market price
All firms produce identical products

questions.text: What is a natural monopoly?
options: #A monopoly that arises because a single firm can supply a good or service to an entire market at a lower cost than could two or more firms
A monopoly that is created by the government
A monopoly that exists because a firm owns a key resource
A monopoly that occurs in industries with high research and development costs

questions.text: A firm in a monopolistic market faces a:
options: #Downward-sloping demand curve
Horizontal demand curve
Vertical demand curve
Upward-sloping demand curve

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the term 'externality'?
options: #The uncompensated impact of one person's actions on the well-being of a bystander
The internal costs that a firm incurs during production
The benefits that a consumer receives from purchasing a good
The taxes that a government imposes on a specific industry

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a positive externality?
options: #A person getting a flu shot, which reduces the chance of others getting sick
A factory polluting a nearby river
A neighbor playing loud music late at night
A firm's increased production leading to more traffic congestion

questions.text: What does a point inside the production possibilities frontier indicate?
options: #Resources are not being used efficiently
The economy is producing at its maximum potential
The chosen combination of goods is impossible to produce
There is no opportunity cost involved in moving to the frontier

questions.text: If an economy is operating on its PPF, what does this imply?
options: #All of the above
The economy is using all its resources efficiently
There is no way to produce more of one good without producing less of another
The economy is experiencing full employment

questions.text: What happens to equilibrium price and quantity when demand increases while supply remains constant?
options: #Both price and quantity increase
Price increases and quantity decreases
Price decreases and quantity increases
Both price and quantity decrease

questions.text: In the law of demand, what is the relationship between price and quantity demanded?
options: #Inverse relationship
Direct relationship
No relationship
Proportional relationship

questions.text: When supply decreases while demand remains constant, what happens?
options: #Price increases and quantity decreases
Price decreases and quantity increases
Both price and quantity increase
Both price and quantity decrease

questions.text: If the cross-price elasticity between two goods is positive, what can we conclude?
options: #The two goods are substitutes
The two goods are complements
One of the goods is an inferior good
The demand for both goods is perfectly inelastic

questions.text: What does the term 'elasticity of demand' measure?
options: #How much the quantity demanded responds to a change in price
The slope of the demand curve
The total revenue generated by a firm
The impact of a change in income on the quantity demanded

questions.text: If the government imposes a price ceiling below equilibrium, what occurs?
options: #A shortage
A surplus
Equilibrium is maintained
The quantity supplied increases

questions.text: Which factor is likely to shift the supply curve to the right?
options: #An improvement in production technology
An increase in the cost of raw materials
A decrease in the number of sellers in the market
An increase in the price of the good itself

questions.text: How does demand for a luxury good change when income increases?
options: #It increases by a larger percentage than the increase in income
It increases by the same percentage as the increase in income
It decreases
It remains constant

questions.text: What is the situation called when quantity demanded exceeds quantity supplied?
options: #Shortage
Surplus
Equilibrium
Market failure

questions.text: How is the price elasticity of demand calculated?
options: #Percentage change in quantity demanded divided by percentage change in price
Percentage change in price divided by percentage change in quantity demanded
Change in quantity demanded divided by change in price
Change in price divided by change in quantity demanded

questions.text: If a good has many substitutes, what happens to its price elasticity?
options: #It tends to be more elastic
It tends to be more inelastic
It becomes perfectly inelastic
The number of substitutes has no effect on elasticity

questions.text: What happens to equilibrium price and quantity when both demand and supply decrease?
options: #Quantity decreases, but the effect on price is ambiguous
Price decreases, but the effect on quantity is ambiguous
Both price and quantity decrease
Both price and quantity increase

questions.text: What is the relationship between elasticity of demand and total revenue?
options: #If demand is elastic, a price increase will decrease total revenue
If demand is inelastic, a price increase will decrease total revenue
If demand is unit elastic, a price change will significantly change total revenue
Elasticity of demand has no relationship with total revenue

questions.text: When the government imposes a tax, how do equilibrium price and quantity change?
options: #Price paid by buyers increases and quantity sold decreases
Price paid by buyers decreases and quantity sold increases
Price received by sellers increases and quantity sold decreases
Price paid by buyers increases and quantity sold increases

questions.text: If price falls and total revenue rises, what is the elasticity of demand?
options: #Elastic
Inelastic
Unit elastic
Perfectly inelastic

questions.text: What does elasticity of demand indicate when the coefficient is greater than one?
options: #The demand is elastic
The demand is inelastic
The demand is unit elastic
The good is a necessity

questions.text: If the price of a good increases by 10% and quantity demanded decreases by 20%, what is the elasticity?
In which scenario is demand most elastic?
options: #A specific brand of cereal
Food in general
Gasoline in the short run
Water for drinking

questions.text: What is the elasticity of demand for a perfectly inelastic good?
options: #Zero
One
Infinity
Greater than one

questions.text: If cross-price elasticity is negative, what does it imply?
options: #The two goods are complements
The two goods are substitutes
One of the goods is an inferior good
The demand for the goods is highly elastic

questions.text: What does a perfectly elastic supply curve look like?
options: #A horizontal line
A vertical line
An upward-sloping line starting from the origin
A downward-sloping line

questions.text: If percentage change in quantity supplied exceeds percentage change in price, what is supply elasticity?
options: #Greater than one (elastic)
Less than one (inelastic)
Equal to one (unit elastic)
Zero (perfectly inelastic)

questions.text: Why is supply more elastic in the long run than in the short run?
options: #Firms have more time to build new factories or for new firms to enter the market
Consumers' tastes and preferences change more slowly over time
The government is more likely to intervene in the long run
Short-run production is always more efficient

questions.text: What is the definition of fixed costs?
options: #Costs that do not vary with the quantity of output produced
Costs that increase directly with the quantity of output produced
Costs that only occur when the firm is profitable
The costs associated with hiring additional labor

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of variable costs in manufacturing?
options: #Raw materials
Rent on a factory building
Interest payments on a long-term loan
The salary of the CEO

questions.text: What does 'opportunity cost' mean in production?
options: #The value of the next best alternative that must be foregone
The total cost of all inputs used in production
The cost of the most expensive input used
The amount of profit a firm could have made

questions.text: Which cost represents the additional cost of producing one more unit?
options: #Marginal cost
Average total cost
Variable cost
Fixed cost

questions.text: What is the formula for total cost?
options: #Fixed Cost + Variable Cost
Average Fixed Cost + Average Variable Cost
Marginal Cost x Quantity
Fixed Cost / Quantity

questions.text: What is the formula for average variable cost?
options: #Variable Cost / Quantity
Total Cost / Quantity
Change in Total Cost / Change in Quantity
Fixed Cost / Quantity

questions.text: Which of the following is an implicit cost?
options: #The foregone interest on the owner's own money invested in the business
The wages paid to employees
The rent paid for factory space
The cost of raw materials

questions.text: What is the purpose of calculating the break-even point?
options: #To determine the level of output at which total revenue equals total cost
To find the level of output that maximizes profit
To identify the point where marginal cost equals marginal revenue
To calculate the total taxes owed by the firm

questions.text: In a monopoly, the firm is a:
options: #Price maker
Price taker
Profit taker
Market follower

questions.text: Which market structure is characterized by few interdependent firms?
options: #Oligopoly
Monopoly
Perfect competition
Monopolistic competition

questions.text: Why do firms differentiate products in monopolistic competition?
options: #To gain some control over the price of their product
To lower their total production costs
To comply with government regulations
Because consumers demand identical products

questions.text: A firm in perfect competition maximizes profit where:
options: #Marginal Revenue = Marginal Cost
Price = Average Total Cost
Total Revenue is at its maximum
Average Variable Cost is at its minimum

questions.text: Which market structure typically exhibits non-price competition?
options: #Monopolistic competition
Perfect competition
Pure monopoly
None of the above

questions.text: What does the Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) measure?
options: #Market concentration
The degree of product differentiation
The profitability of a firm
Consumer surplus

questions.text: When will a perfectly competitive firm shut down in the short run?
options: #If Price < Average Variable Cost
If Price < Average Total Cost
If Total Revenue < Total Cost
If Marginal Revenue < Marginal Cost

questions.text: What does GDP stand for?
options: #Gross Domestic Product
Global Development Program
General Domestic Price
Gross Demand Potential

questions.text: What is the economic term for satisfaction from consuming a good?
options: #Utility
Profit
Surplus
Elasticity

questions.text: Compute equilibrium quantity using: Qd = 20 − 2p and Qs = −10 + 2p.
In the circular flow model, what do households provide to firms?
options: #Factors of production (labor, land, capital)
Goods and services
Wages and salaries
Tax revenue

questions.text: In a closed economy without government, what are the two primary markets?
options: #Markets for goods/services and markets for factors of production
The stock market and the bond market
The domestic market and the international market
The consumer market and the industrial market

questions.text: When economists say "people face trade-offs," what do they mean?
options: #To get one thing that we like, we usually have to give up another thing that we like
Life is always full of difficult and unhappy choices
Every decision has a negative consequence
Trading goods is the only way to improve welfare

questions.text: Which example demonstrates "thinking at the margin"?
options: #Deciding whether to stay in school for one more year
Deciding whether to go to college or start working after high school
Choosing which career path to follow for the rest of your life
Calculating the total cost of a four-year degree

questions.text: How do economists define incentives?
options: #Something that induces a person to act
The internal drive to succeed
A government regulation that limits choice
A person's natural preference for a particular good

questions.text: What does "trade can make everyone better off" imply?
options: #Trade allows people to specialize and enjoy a greater variety of goods
Trade ensures that everyone gets an equal amount of resources
Trade eliminates the need for any government intervention
Trade always results in a surplus for all participating nations

questions.text: In market principles, what does a competitive market lead to?
options: #An efficient allocation of resources
The highest possible prices for consumers
The guaranteed survival of every firm
Total equality among all members of society

questions.text: What describes the government's role in correcting market failure?
options: #Intervening to improve efficiency when the market fails to allocate resources well on its own
Nationalizing all major industries to ensure they are run fairly
Fixing prices to make sure goods are affordable
Eliminating all competition to prevent market instability

questions.text: Which situation represents an externality?
options: #Second-hand smoke from a neighbor's cigarette
Buying a used car from a private seller
Paying a higher price for a good because of a tax
Working overtime to earn extra money

questions.text: Which statement reflects that living standards depend on production?
options: #A country's standard of living depends on its ability to produce goods and services
Living standards are purely determined by a country's natural resources
The government's ability to print money is the key to a high standard of living
High living standards are only possible in countries with low taxes

questions.text: Which principle explains inflation?
options: #Prices rise when the government prints too much money
Prices rise when there is a decrease in the demand for goods
Prices fall when the supply of money increases
Inflation is caused by high levels of unemployment

questions.text: "No free lunch" illustrates which principle?
options: #People face trade-offs
Rational people think at the margin
Incentives matter
Trade can make everyone better off

questions.text: What represents the idea that markets organize economic activity well?
options: #The 'invisible hand' guiding the actions of buyers and sellers
The strict oversight of a central planning committee
The use of bartering in local communities
The establishment of trade barriers to protect domestic markets

questions.text: Which scenario could improve a country's standard of living?
options: #An increase in the productivity of its workers
A decrease in the total amount of goods produced
A significant increase in the national debt
A rise in the overall price level (inflation)

questions.text: What does "trade can make everyone better off" imply for international trade?
options: #Countries benefit from being able to trade with one another
Trade is a zero-sum game where one country's gain is another's loss
All countries should try to be self-sufficient and avoid trade
Trade only benefits wealthy nations

questions.text: Which scenario reflects marginal thinking?
options: #An airline selling a last-minute seat for less than the average cost per seat
A person deciding to buy a whole new wardrobe
A firm choosing to shut down its entire operations
A government deciding to change its entire economic system

questions.text: What is the short-run trade-off between inflation and unemployment?
options: #Reducing inflation often leads to a temporary increase in unemployment
Higher unemployment always leads to higher inflation
There is no relationship between inflation and unemployment
Policies that reduce unemployment will always reduce inflation as well

questions.text: Which factor directly affects national productivity?
options: #The skills and knowledge of the workforce (human capital)
The total amount of money in circulation
The number of holidays in a year
The specific political party in power

questions.text: Why do people face trade-offs?
options: #Because resources are scarce
Because people are naturally greedy
Because the government imposes limits on what we can do
Because markets are inherently inefficient

questions.text: Why do economists use assumptions?
options: #To simplify the complex world and make it easier to understand
Because they do not have enough data to be accurate
To ensure that their models always support their personal values
Because economics is not a true science

questions.text: Which is an example of a positive statement?
options: #The unemployment rate is currently 5%
The government should do more to reduce unemployment
High unemployment is the biggest problem facing the country
It is better to have low inflation than low unemployment

questions.text: What does an outward shift of the PPF represent?
options: #Economic growth
A decrease in resources
An increase in the unemployment rate
A shift in consumer preferences toward one good

questions.text: Which is a normative statement?
options: #The inheritance tax should be abolished because it is unfair
The inheritance tax generates $10 billion in revenue annually
The inheritance tax only applies to very wealthy estates
Many other countries also have inheritance taxes

questions.text: What does "ceteris paribus" mean?
options: #All other things being equal
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction
The buyer must beware
Nothing is certain except death and taxes

questions.text: What defines absolute advantage?
options: #The ability to produce a good using fewer inputs than another producer
The ability to produce a good at a lower opportunity cost than another producer
The ability to sell a good at a higher price than another producer
Having more total resources than another producer

questions.text: What must a country consider in comparative advantage?
options: #The opportunity cost of producing a good
The total amount of labor available in the country
The absolute number of goods it can produce
The level of technology in other countries

questions.text: Given two countries' production capabilities, which has comparative advantage?
options: #The country with the lower opportunity cost for a specific good
The country that can produce more of both goods
The country with the more advanced technology
The country that has the absolute advantage in both goods

questions.text: The "gains from trade" concept relies on which theory?
options: #Comparative advantage
Absolute advantage
The labor theory of value
The theory of mercantilism

questions.text: Which scenario best illustrates interdependence?
options: #A country relying on others for goods it cannot produce efficiently itself
A family growing all of its own food and making its own clothes
A firm producing every component of its final product in-house
An individual living alone in the wilderness

questions.text: Why do economists focus on opportunity cost in trade analysis?
options: #Because it is the true cost of choosing one activity over another
Because it is easier to calculate than monetary cost
Because opportunity cost is only relevant in international trade
Because it helps to justify government intervention in markets
